conclusion: To determine the pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K, we can use the information provided in the p-T graph.
The p-T graph shows a linear relationship between pressure (p) and temperature (T).
From the graph, we can see two points: At T = 200 K, p = 0.5 × 10⁵ Pa; At T = 400 K, p = 1.0 × 10⁵ Pa.
The slope (m) of the line is calculated as m = Δp/ΔT = (1.0 × 10⁵ Pa - 0.5 × 10⁵ Pa) / (400 K - 200 K) = 0.25 × 10³ Pa/K.
Using the point-slope form of a line p = mT + c, where c is the y-intercept. Using the point (200 K, 0.5 × 10⁵ Pa), c = 0.
Substitute T = 600 K into the equation: p = 0.25 × 10³ × 600 = 1.5 × 10⁵ Pa.
The pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K is 1.5 × 10⁵ Pa.
